pros: Everyone is very nice and caring, good environment to work in
cons: low wages compared to others

pros: Faculty and Students are amazing. Small town. Beautiful campus.
cons: No raises (yearly raises are below inflation). Benefits are cut often. Increased workload year over year with no compensation. Extreme discrimination within departments.

review_title: Tenure Track Professor, Small Liberal Arts University
job_title: Tenure Track Professor in Ada, OH
pros: Many great colleagues and students
cons: Recent restructuring wasn't thought out

pros: Nice homey atmosphere and generally friendly
cons: Too slow to make changes

job_title: Retired associate professor in Lima, OH
pros: Close knit, family style academic community
cons: Budget difficulties causing academic support issues

review_title: Not what it used to be
pros: Great students and town environment
cons: Professors not supported by administration

pros: I had 20 days of paid vacation and 20 days of paid sick leave each. These days could roll over so you could have up to 40 days of each saved. We got a week off every year for Christmas because the university was shut down.
cons: Small down and not a lot of collaboration across departments

pros:
VERY laid back - but to the point where nothing important that needs addressed gets done in any sort of timely fashion

Tuition Remission
cons: No opportunity for raises - different expectations for every employee even though the job titles are the same.

pros: Fun job fun job low key
cons: Bad pay, had to stay on meal plan

review_title: Was a beneficial role for me
pros: This was a work study position
cons: They only paid minimum wage

review_title: You will never get the resources you need to meet their expectations.
pros: The health insurance was not bad if you did not have a family.  The location was close enough to interesting place that you could go to for a day or weekend.
cons: The provost denies people tenure and promotions if they do not publish in areas outside their dissertations.  Basically, the work you did in graduate school that was supposed to launch your career is  considered worthless here, and with your heavy course load, you will never have the time you need to do the new research projects the administration now demands for promotion.  You will not have much in terms of financial resources, either, as every year presents a new crisis in which the university struggles to meet its budget.

pros: All pros that used to be true for this institution no longer are.
cons: A select 75 employees in all areas of the university were awarded raises this year on the basis that they were earning less than 90% of the CUPA average.  Everyone else got no raise, again.  There has been only one small raise for everyone in the last 5 years.  The administration has also awarded a punitive pay decrease to a faculty member, with no prior notice that this measure could and would be taken.  It appears that the only way you can get a raise is to be severely underpaid already.  Plus, the provost is increasing the requirements for tenure and promotions with no faculty input.  The way he has chosen to communicate his new requirements is to deny faculty members tenure and promotions.

pros: People are its best asset.  Most are nice and are focused onmaking the University better.
cons: Highly political with ancient policies and practices. Externally the appear to embrace modern business practices, comforts and technology but administratively this place is a nightmare. The culture is almost incetious as they prefer to hire former grads that romantacize the ideals the University lived by when they were students there.

review_title: The job is good for the pay, but has a poor environment
pros: The pay is and work load is spot on for a security job. You also get to interact with a lot of different people.
cons: There is little room for promotion in the department. Management looks down on security so you end up taking the blame for student disputes.

pros: Flexible schedule, great co-workers, strong leadership. It's a fun office and giving tours to prospective students is a really rewarding experience. All of the people who work here are awesome, I actually found one of my best roommates in this office.
cons: While being a full-time student, it can be difficult to get enough hours. If you don't like stuffing envelopes, this is not the job for you. The pay isn't awesome but it's good for a part-time, college position.

job_title: Bear Ambassador (Student Tour Guide) in Ada, OH
pros: Flexible schedule, dynamic environment, work that feels like it makes a difference, working with awesome people, meeting prospective students, getting to enjoy the weather when it is nice out, 10% discount in university book store
cons: Minimum wage, tours will happen regardless of how the weather is (rain, snow, ice, wind, etc.)

pros: The students are wonderful, and the benefits are okay.
cons: Tenure and promotion standards are written, but  committees and administration are choosing not to abide by them.  Administration believes that faculty must publish a high number of articles (more than 2) while carrying a heavy teaching load (4-4 in the College of Arts and Sciences), but administration will not state expectations publicly.

pros: Unbelievable people who provided great opportunities to grow. Good pays. Friends to be made.
cons: Horrible food. Some weird people. Very, very cold in the winter time.

job_title: Writing Center Tutor in Ada, OH
pros: The environment is welcoming, and there is typically downtime for school work. It picks up around midterms and gets busy.
cons: The pay is not a lot. It won't pay the rent.

pros: Family environment and very safe
cons: Little room for career advancement. Salaries are far below average.

pros: Liberal time off.  Stable.  Very flexible!  Family oriented.
cons: Pay could be better but pros far outweigh cons

pros: Good Distance and Great employers
cons: Slight Varying Levels of Experience

review_title: I loved the people I worked with

cons: Job got boring at times

pros: I enjoyed working at onu. Generous PTO
